title: KKDD
text:
KKDD (1290 <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM</a>) is a <a href="radio%20station">radio station</a> in <a href="San%20Bernardino%2C%20California">San Bernardino, California</a>. The station is owned by <a href="Relevant%20Radio">Relevant Radio</a>, Inc. It airs a <a href="Christian%20radio">Catholic</a> <a href="talk%20radio">talk</a> <a href="radio%20format">format</a> for the <a href="Inland%20Empire">Inland Empire</a> region of <a href="Southern%20California">Southern California</a> including <a href="Riverside%2C%20California">Riverside</a> and San Bernardino.
History.
In 1947, the radio station first <a href="sign-on">signed on</a> as KITO, owned by the San Bernardino Broadcasting Company. It was a <a href="network%20affiliate">network affiliate</a> of <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>, carrying its schedule of dramas, comedies, news, sports, <a href="soap%20opera">soap opera</a>s and <a href="big%20band">big band</a> broadcasts during the <a href="Golden%20Age%20of%20Radio">Golden Age of Radio</a>. In the 1950s, it changed its network affiliation to the <a href="Mutual%20Broadcasting%20System">Mutual Broadcasting System</a> and <a href="Don%20Lee%20Network">Don Lee Network</a>.
In 1962, the station was bought by Radio Associates, Inc., which switched it to a <a href="contemporary%20hit%20radio">Top 40</a> sound as KMEN, known on the air as "K/men 129". In the competitive Top 40 format, K/men 129 battled crosstown rival <a href="AM%20590">AM 590</a> KFXM (now <a href="KTIE">KTIE</a>) for youthful ratings. As Top 40 listening shifted to <a href="FM%20radio">FM radio</a> in the 1980s, KMEN tried a variety of formats, including <a href="middle%20of%20the%20road%20%28music%29">middle of the road</a>, <a href="oldies">oldies</a> and <a href="talk%20radio">talk</a>. While the <a href="Las%20Vegas%20Raiders">Las Vegas Raiders</a> <a href="American%20football">football</a> team played in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, KMEN was the <a href="Inland%20Empire">Inland Empire</a> affiliate.
In 1997, Chancellor Broadcasting, bought KMEN, flipping the format to <a href="adult%20standards">adult standards</a>. In September 1998, The station <a href="call%20sign">call sign</a> was changed to KKDD, which refers to KiDs, and the station switched to a <a href="children%27s%20radio">children's radio</a> format, featuring music and programming from the <a href="Radio%20Disney">Radio Disney</a> network. In 2000, Chancellor Broadcasting merged with Clear Channel Communications (now <a href="iHeartMedia">iHeartMedia</a>). 
On April 3, 2012, ERC Media signed a <a href="local%20marketing%20agreement">local marketing agreement</a> (LMA) with Clear Channel, allowing the company to program the station with a mix of <a href="Contemporary%20Christian%20music">Contemporary Christian music</a> and <a href="Brokered%20programming">brokered</a> religious teaching programs. During this time, the station's programming originated from the <a href="Orange%20County%2C%20California">Orange County</a> studios of 107.9 <a href="KWVE-FM">KWVE-FM</a>, a longtime <a href="Christian%20radio">Christian radio</a> station.
On April 11, 2014, ERC Media's LMA expired and Clear Channel resumed programming KKDD, this time with a <a href="Spanish-language">Spanish-language</a> <a href="adult%20hits">adult hits</a> format branded as "La Preciosa 1290."
On May 15, 2017, 1290 KKDD swapped formats with <a href="sister%20station">sister station</a> <a href="KFOO%20%28AM%29">KFNY</a> in Riverside. 1290 KKDD became a talk station, while KFNY became "La Presciosa 1440."
On October 1, 2020, iHeartMedia and Immaculate Heart Media announced a swap in which KKDD, along with <a href="W292DH">W292DH</a> in Pittsburgh, would be acquired by Immaculate Heart in exchange for <a href="WXBN%20%28AM%29">WZAB</a> in Miami; the swap saw KKDD join the Relevant Radio network.
